comments.commentBody: Or the Republican manicured lawn, privacy fence, in-ground swimming pool suburbs?
Me neither.
I agree that  BE IN/ BANANA is funnier. Hadn't thought of it.

As for including LGBTs in the grid, I don't think DLW was creating a political statement here so much as clever word play.

And if you haven't read or seen The Crucible, Nick, you should -- you would appreciate its timely theme, which is not revenge, but social injustice and hysteria.
Actually, I suppose that 47a could have been clued as 'Order from Capote?' or something like that. Though that would have given it an element not present in the other theme clues.

Good puzzle, a tad easier than yesterday. The theme was good solving wise; Can I ask that NO ONE make ANY kind of political comment, since it'll make me feel like I'm at the wrong end of a double standard.

Moving on, unknowns included LOC, TRIAL (I'd like to see a revenge movie about a witch in those days!), and DIEU, with quite a few barely knowns I sussed out from perps.

Would've been nice if some of the people clued had been LGBT, even if said people are barely known my most solvers.

I guess it is Wednesday, but I'd still prefer BEIN crossed with BANANA.

Whether you are a conservative or a liberal, Republican or a Democrat, the time has come for America to turn it's back on the kind of hateful, divisive, and paranoid garbage promulgated by the Beck's, Palin's and Limbaughs of the world. They are not only bad for America, but bad for the Republican Party.

That aside, in Romney's refusal to release his tax returns, he may be showing us, at long last, the only authentic window into who he really is.

Mitt Romney wants us to trust him as our president, but how can we trust him if he doesn't even trust what our reaction would be to his own record? The fact is, we can't trust Romney, and a release of his returns prior to 2010 will probably confirm that.

Either Romney is so politically obtuse in that he can't gauge the growing chorus of those who demand he release his returns -- even Bill Kristol, Mathew Dowd, and George Will call for him to release them -- or he has skeletons in the closet that he feels might sink his presidential ship.

With either scenario, Romney is stumbling (badly) and not looking at all like the leader he claims to be.

When Romney is confronted and pressed to offer something of substance about his record, something that we can match against what he's been saying throughout the campaign, he balks and can't do it. He balks because he knows it will confirm what so many of his detractors have been saying all along: he is not a leader; he's not right for America; he is representative of the problem.

Thank you for posting the piece -- but this is not news! :)  I mean, maybe it really is news to some people, but it seems to me to be rather intuitive that sports can improve teenagers' health. Exercise is proving absolutely crucial, whatever our age.

Soccer is cheap, too. I play twice a week with friends. We've played for three years. We have a few "pinnies" that we wear to indicate teams and a ball. We use the nets that are on our local recreation field. My (used) cleats and cost $15 and my shin guards about $10. In the winter we play inside. We play in the cafeteria of our local elementary school and tape old pillowcases up on the wall to use as goals.

We have derived more fun from these simple items than words can describe.

I wish to add to my recent post that the mention of individual sports in the article is just as important as the mentions of team sports. Running (my favorite sport of all time, I admit) is one of the most accessible and inexpensive of all strenuous physical activities, and can be a high pleasure for many children, teenagers and adults worldwide.

I haven't been a kid in school for a long time -- and I know the budgetary cuts have hit sports and gym programs hard. But my recollection of sports in elementary and high school was that it is largely aimed at the gifted child athletes -- the kids who are swift, coordinated, strong ALREADY.

The clumsy kid, the overweight kid -- he or she sits on the sidelines, while the "superstar" gets to play or climb or run. Or they have the "pleasure" of being "it" when a group plays something like dodge ball.

Our cultural sports mentality is geared to "winners" -- it does not include or emphasize bringing everyone to a moderate level of success.

I am also trying to process just how many sports teams -- how many TYPES of sports teams -- this theory would include -- 2 a year, for ALL children, sounds very costly and labor & equipment intensive.

Yes, some sports programs at schools are geared towards the superstarts.  However that is the concept of JV and Varsity and if a school does it right, keeps JV open for everyone it can work.  But it takes funds and committment by the school.
and where are all these opportunities for school sports to come from if every child is on 2 teams?  are you proposing multiple teams in each sport? as the saying goes, there is only one ball.

Mouse, most obese children have one or both parents who are obese -- they were born to an overweight mother much of the time, and subjected to too high glucose and starches (even in the absence of gestational diabetes) in the womb.

Certainly behaviors and examples are a big part of this, but I know vegan parents who have overweight kids. Studies of twins should that even twins raised completely apart, in radically different families, ended up at the same weight as the other twin in adulthood!

Probably it is about 75% genetics and 25% environment, or some similar mix. Genes load the gun; behaviors fire it off.

Guess what? I was overweight in high school, yet I played on three varsity sports teams all four years. And I was an active participant. Swim team (500 yard swim was my best event), soccer, and track & field (though I was on the "field" side, we still had to run countless laps). So please, tell me how my overweight parents discouraged me from playing sports.

The headline should really be "Parents Promote Healthy Weight in Teenagers".

Most obese children have obese parents from whom they learn their eating and exercise habits.
Yes, that's how we do it here too. Shameful.
Yours are not the real issue the real issue is equal treatment under the law

@Hanker So 'that's' why Kobe and Jordan aren't thought of as some of the greatest players to grace the NBA... they weren't playing in NY. I was beginning to wonder if all those championships were a waste or something.

Hey SteelJab - I've been a Knicks fan since '67 and listened to Marv call every home game on the RADIO in those days. What was great about the '69 - '73 teams was INTELLIGENCE and UNSELFISHNESS as well as talent, characteristics that have been conspicuously abcent from their teams since. Lin had more smarts than any Knicks point guard since Clyde, and instead we have more age and mediocraty. I'm done, and it didn't happen overnight - got that?

Linsanity was fun while it lasted. However, due to the financial impact of that balloon payment and the uncertainty of Lin's ability coming off knee surgery the risk really didn't make sense for the Knicks.

Time will tell.
Maybe Houston would be willing to trade Lin back to NY in return for the space shuttle Enterprise...
before Lin ,Who is Knick??What is Knick????
Amen.  I wrote my comment before reading yours.  I hope there are a lot of us out there that realize the Knicks just went from being, potentially, a playoff contender to being Iso-Melo all the time.
It's Melo's team.  One and done in the playoffs - if they're lucky. Back to not really following the Knicks too closely. But the Nets look really interesting.
Fields is horrible bub

The upside is that Lin & Fields are now rich and free of Melo, who won't make it past the first round without that kid with the "rediculous" contract.

Melo & JR Smith went nowhere in Denver in the playoffs because they are selfish players with no basketball IQ.

Don't expect Amar'e & Felton to succeed with the pick & roll - Melo won't let that happen, just as he refused to play hard for D'Antoni. It's got to go through him.

More boring frustrating ball coming up at MSG!

So, good job Dolan, first trading a young, fun & winning group to get Melo, and now this. You clearly don't understand the game, but it's your team, and I am moving on after more than 4 decades as a fan. May your stock price continue to drop until you are forced to sell..

Bummer. Lin was the most exciting player in years for the Knicks. He made the players around him better. The offense was fluid and lovely to watch. I couldn't wait to see him next season. Why didn't the Knicks make a deal with him earlier? Why did it come to this? How could they lose him? Truly Linsanity.

Yeah, the MLB was very popular in the late 1990's and early 2000's when steroid usage was rampant and there was no drug testing policy in place and we were seeing home runs flying all over the place. Those games were so exciting to watch. Nonetheless, the players were for sure using drugs. And you know what, they are going to vote on Barry Bonds or Roger Clemens getting to the HOF next year because not many professional players could accomplish their feats even with the help of steroids.
Why, as a nation, we can't simply take a look at what have been going on? So we just should let the Wall Street villains walk away, is it what you're saying?
I don't think any of the BALCO clients actually got caught testing positive. Yet, they're striped off the medals they won "supposedly" during the years they had used drugs.

All things being equal, you were the best.

Just put on your big boy underwear, cop to it, and move on.

America loves a redemption story.

Simeoni admitted that he was doping long before ever consulted Ferrari to help him dope more successfully, yet he testified against Ferrari and made disparaging remarks about Armstrong and other active riders in the peloton. Armstrong responded to Simeoni's attacks in the press with his usual candor and Simeoni responded by suing Armstrong for defamation. It was with this background that Stage 18 of the 2004 Tour took place.

There certainly was no love lost between Armstrong and Simeoni, and Armstrong's actions in chasing down the break that Simeoni had bridged to, and persuading Simeoni to rejoin the peloton, were widely applauded by many who were fed up with a confessed doper who made repeated comments to the press that denigrated individual cyclists and professional cycling in general.

It was well-known that Ferrari counseled some athletes using PEDs, but he was nonetheless highly regarded for his knowledge of sports medicine. Training at altitude and sleeping in low-oxygen atmospheres in a tent were among the many legal techniques that Ferrari also counseled.

So you are entitled to think Armstrong acted inappropriately as the patron of the peloton in disciplining Simeoni, but its hardly evidence that Armstrong used illegal performance-enhancing drugs.

And if rumors, the claims of acknowledged and threatened cheats, and objectionable social behavior replace drug tests as proof, then where will you find the clean sportsman you'd like to protect?

I followed the Tour de France for many years, starting when Armstrong was a part of it. I fell in love with the strategy, the strength, and the suffering of the teams.

I believed in Lance. But then I saw some strange things.

Many of Lance's teammates were busted for cheating after they left Lance's team. It was like they were safe under his umbrella ($$$), but when they went solo, their safety net vanished.
And one year when Lance (in yellow) did a solo (!) chase down of a non-threat for yellow in a small break-away (the Italian rider Simeoni who testified against a "friend" of Lance's- Dr. Ferrari), and brought him back to the peloton, I saw Lance for the bully he is.
He gets away with it because of his foundation. He should know that cancer bike-a-thons and awareness will continue with or without him or his name.
I hope the truth prevails, for all the clean sportsmen and women out there.

Personally I say thank you to Mr. Tygart and his team for trying to bring some accountability here.  He is just doing his job, and does not do it lightly.  Most people I know in our local cycling club agree.  Mr. Tygart knew he would face the wrath of Lance & his entitled 1% mentality, including the army of lawyers, lobbyists, public relations handlers, etc. that Lance's ill-gotten millions can buy (similar to his fellow Texan Roger Clemens).  Honestly, hasn't Lance profited enough from his cheating?   He should be a man and admit it.

Memphis Richard: I was making no judgment as to the propriety of the comment (for the record: yes, it's completely inappropriate for a Congressman to heckle the President).  It's just that this is the New York Times--the "newspaper of record"--and it's writers and fact checkers should be well-aware that Joe Wilson heckled the President during his speech on healthcare, not during the State of the Union.  So, yes, facts matter.
Agreed, Richard.  I did not think that the person quoted here believed that such behavior was expected as part of the live comedy experience.
